outbreak_types.formula: An outbreak is a sudden rise in disease cases; epidemics are regional while pandemics are global
outbreak_types.correct: Epidemics occur within a defined geographic region or community; pandemics spread across continents or globally

wrong.answer: Epidemics are more widespread than pandemics
wrong.fix: Pandemics are larger (global); epidemics are smaller (regional/community)
wrong.action: Epidemic = local/regional; Pandemic = global/intercontinental

wrong.answer: Outbreaks only occur with new diseases
wrong.fix: Outbreaks can occur with new pathogens or re-emerging known pathogens
wrong.action: Outbreaks: new pathogens OR re-emerging pathogens in susceptible populations

wrong.answer: Epidemics and pandemics are identical
wrong.fix: The key difference is geographic spread: epidemic (regional) vs pandemic (global)
wrong.action: Scale matters: epidemic < pandemic in geographic spread

outbreak_drivers.formula: Outbreaks are driven by globalisation, deforestation, and climate change introducing pathogens to susceptible populations
outbreak_drivers.correct: Travel spreads pathogens globally; habitat loss increases human-wildlife contact; climate change alters vector distributions

wrong.answer: Modern outbreaks only occur in developing countries
wrong.fix: Globalisation means outbreaks can spread anywhere rapidly through travel and trade
wrong.action: Global travel = global disease spread potential

wrong.answer: Climate change has no effect on disease spread
wrong.fix: Climate change alters vector breeding cycles and geographic range (e.g., mosquitoes)
wrong.action: Warmer climate = expanded vector habitats = new disease regions

wrong.answer: Deforestation prevents disease outbreaks
wrong.fix: Deforestation forces wildlife closer to humans, increasing zoonotic disease risk
wrong.action: Habitat loss = human-wildlife contact = zoonotic spillover

colonial_impact.formula: European colonisation introduced epidemic diseases that devastated Indigenous Australian populations lacking immunity
colonial_impact.correct: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples had no prior exposure to diseases like smallpox, measles, and influenza

wrong.answer: Indigenous Australians had natural immunity to European diseases
wrong.fix: No prior exposure meant no immunity; mortality rates were extremely high
wrong.action: No exposure = no immunity = devastating epidemics

wrong.answer: European diseases had minimal impact on Indigenous populations
wrong.fix: Diseases like smallpox killed an estimated 50-70% of Indigenous populations in affected areas
wrong.action: European diseases = major cause of Indigenous population decline

wrong.answer: Only disease caused harm to Indigenous populations
wrong.fix: Colonisation also disrupted lifestyles, diet, and sanitation, increasing disease susceptibility
wrong.action: Disease + social disruption + malnutrition = compounded impact

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of colonial disease impact
persistent.action: Factors: no immunity, lifestyle disruption, malnutrition, poor sanitation

antigenic_drift.formula: Antigenic drift is gradual change in viral surface proteins through accumulation of point mutations
antigenic_drift.correct: Small mutations over time change epitopes so that existing antibodies may no longer recognise the virus

wrong.answer: Antigenic drift causes sudden dramatic changes
wrong.fix: Drift is gradual (point mutations); shift is sudden (gene reassortment)
wrong.action: Drift = gradual/minor; Shift = sudden/major

wrong.answer: Antigenic drift only affects bacteria
wrong.fix: Antigenic drift specifically refers to viral mutation, especially in influenza
wrong.action: Drift and shift are viral concepts (especially flu)

wrong.answer: Antigenic drift makes vaccines permanently effective
wrong.fix: Drift requires regular vaccine updates as the virus gradually changes
wrong.action: Drift = seasonal flu vaccines needed annually

persistent.gap: Confusion between antigenic drift and shift
persistent.action: Drift: point mutations → gradual change → seasonal updates needed

antigenic_shift.formula: Antigenic shift is sudden major change when two viral strains reassort their gene segments in a co-infected cell
antigenic_shift.correct: Shift creates entirely new viral subtypes to which populations have no immunity, potentially causing pandemics

wrong.answer: Antigenic shift occurs through gradual mutation
wrong.fix: Shift is sudden reassortment of gene segments; drift is gradual point mutations
wrong.action: Shift = sudden (reassortment); Drift = gradual (mutations)

wrong.answer: Antigenic shift cannot cross species barriers
wrong.fix: Shift can create new subtypes that jump species barriers (e.g., bird flu to humans)
wrong.action: Shift can create zoonotic strains → pandemic potential

wrong.answer: Antigenic shift happens every flu season
wrong.fix: Shift is rare but when it occurs, it can cause pandemics; drift is seasonal
wrong.action: Shift = rare but catastrophic; Drift = common and seasonal

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of antigenic shift mechanism
persistent.action: Shift: co-infection → gene reassortment → new subtype → no immunity → pandemic risk

antibiotic_resistance.formula: Antibiotic resistance emerges through natural selection when resistant bacteria survive and reproduce
antibiotic_resistance.correct: Resistant bacteria survive antibiotic treatment, multiply without competition, and can transfer resistance via plasmids

wrong.answer: Antibiotics cause bacteria to become resistant
wrong.fix: Resistance mutations occur randomly; antibiotics select for pre-existing resistant bacteria
wrong.action: Antibiotics don't cause mutations; they select resistant mutants

wrong.answer: Antibiotic resistance cannot spread between bacteria
wrong.fix: Resistance genes can spread via plasmids through bacterial conjugation
wrong.action: Plasmid transfer = resistance spreading to other bacteria

wrong.answer: Narrow-spectrum antibiotics cause more resistance
wrong.fix: Broad-spectrum antibiotics kill more bacteria, creating stronger selection for resistance
wrong.action: Broad-spectrum = more selection pressure = faster resistance emergence

persistent.action: Process: random mutations → antibiotic selection → resistant survive → multiply → spread via conjugation

mrsa.formula: MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) is an example of antibiotic-resistant bacteria difficult to treat
mrsa.correct: MRSA evolved resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics and spreads in healthcare and community settings

wrong.answer: MRSA is resistant to all antibiotics
wrong.fix: MRSA is resistant to methicillin and related antibiotics; some other antibiotics may still work
wrong.action: MRSA = resistant to beta-lactams; other options exist but are limited

wrong.answer: MRSA only occurs in hospitals
wrong.fix: MRSA can be hospital-acquired (HA-MRSA) or community-acquired (CA-MRSA)
wrong.action: MRSA in hospitals AND community settings

wrong.answer: MRSA is a new species of bacteria
wrong.fix: MRSA is a resistant strain of Staphylococcus aureus, not a new species
wrong.action: Same species (S. aureus), resistant strain

persistent.action: MRSA: S. aureus strain, beta-lactam resistant, hospital and community spread

pathogen_emergence.formula: New pathogens emerge through mutation, recombination, and zoonotic spillover from animal reservoirs
pathogen_emergence.correct: Emergence involves pathogens adapting to new hosts or existing pathogens changing antigenicity

wrong.answer: New pathogens always come from laboratories
wrong.fix: Most new pathogens emerge naturally through evolution and zoonotic spillover
wrong.action: Natural emergence: mutation, reassortment, species jumping

wrong.answer: Only viruses can emerge as new pathogens
wrong.error: Limiting emergence to one pathogen type
wrong.fix: Bacteria, fungi, and parasites can also emerge as new pathogens
wrong.action: All pathogen types can emerge or re-emerge

wrong.answer: Pathogen emergence is completely unpredictable
wrong.fix: Monitoring animal reservoirs and human-animal interfaces can help predict emergence
wrong.action: Surveillance of zoonotic hotspots can provide early warning

persistent.action: Emergence pathways: mutation, recombination, zoonotic spillover, antimicrobial resistance
